Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The buddhist friend asks to discuss a recent sermon they attended.
Story: It’s Sunday afternoon, and my phone buzzes with a message from my mom: “How are you? Haven’t heard from you this week.” I glance at the clock, realizing I haven’t checked in since last weekend. Guilt prickles at me; I know how much my parents value our regular chats, even if it’s just a quick text. As I start typing a reply, another message pops up—this time from Tenzin, my friend from the Buddhist center. He’s eager to talk about the sermon we attended yesterday, wanting to reflect on the teachings and share insights. I feel a tug in both directions. My parents expect me to be present, to show I care by keeping in touch. But Tenzin and my Buddhist practice call for my attention too, asking me to engage deeply, to be mindful and present in spiritual conversation. I stare at my phone, torn between the comfort of family and the pull of my spiritual path, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
